awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Reproductive Subjectivity in the Context of Displacement
awd_abstract_narration:
The universal human process of reproduction is imbued with diverse religious, social, and cultural meanings. The interactions, negotiations, and contestations that surround reproductive decisions are a rich source of ethnographic data that speaks to the most intimate aspects of experience, not only in terms of gender roles, marriage, family, and kinship but also in relation to foundational notions of self, personhood, and meaning. Studying reproduction thus reveals many of the fundamental cultural models and interpretive frameworks that individuals use to define what constitutes a good life and strive towards it. Social scientific research on war and displacement has shown how these experiences can transform the cultural frameworks through which individuals interpret and remake their worlds, form novel subjectivities, or cultivate new desires. This project, which trains a graduate student in scientific methods of rigorous data collection and analysis, explores a specific intersection of two domains of human experience: the nearly universal experience of reproduction and the increasingly widespread condition of displacement.

Morgen Chalmiers, under the supervision of Dr. Thomas Csordas of the University of California at San Diego, will explore what factors influence reproductive practices in the context of displacement. It has been well documented that displacement can influence the reproductive experience by disrupting the social and familial networks through which reproductive life is facilitated and made meaningful. But other research has shown that displacement can have a paradoxical effect on fertility patterns, as precarity creates a desire to rebuild kinship and social networks. In seeking to understand in what ways precarity may shape subjectivity, this project examines the context of Syrian displacement, where since the civil war began in 2011, five and a half million Syrians have fled their home country and are now living as refugees. This project explores the intersubjective processes through which Syrian women reconcile histories of trauma and violence with the human imperative to create new meaning in disrupted lives. Over 12 months of ethnographic and person-centered, qualitative interviews fieldwork with displaced Syrian families living in Jordan, this project will ask how reproductive desires and practices are reshaped by the context of displacement. Research at such a junction reveals the creative ways in which individuals cope with the challenges of displacement despite loss and adversity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Reproduction has long been a domain at which existential questions of identity, difference, belonging, responsibility, and obligation are contested as well as a site for the exercise of biopolitical power. Today, as worldwide displacement reaches an all-time high, the reproductive lives and bodies of immigrants, refugees, and asylum-seekers are subject to heightened forms of scrutiny and control--what social scientists refer to as "reproductive governance." In this context, efforts to study and intervene on migrants' reproductive lives have proliferated within academia and the humanitarian sector. However, the bulk of such studies have relied upon methodologies commonly used in public health and the applied sciences while the "experience-near" perspective offered by ethnographic methods seldom appears within this literature. This study aimed to harness the unique insights afforded by feminist ethnography to advance scholarship on reproductive experience among one population of forced migrants: Syrian refugees living in Jordan several years after their displacement. 

As an MD/PhD candidate, Morgen A. Chalmiers sought to understand reproductive experience through a bifocal lens, integrating the historically-deep, contextually-attentive framework adopted by anthropologists with the more applied, clinical perspective developed through her medical training. Building upon scholarship in Critical Refugee Studies and Decolonial Theory, her dissertation project employed a desire-centered approach (Tuck 2009) to elicit women's personal accounts of reproductive experience and critically juxtaposed (Espiritu 2014) these accounts with dominant narratives about refugee women's reproduction circulating in the humanitarian sector. Over the 12-month award period, she conducted ethnographic fieldwork and participant observation with Syrian refugees living in Jordan as well as local and international humanitarian service providers, researchers, and policy-makers working on issues related to reproduction, broadly defined. When ethical considerations precluded in-person research during the Covid-19 pandemic, she volunteered remotely with local NGOs, participating in online trainings and collaborative, qualitative analysis of data previously conducted by these organizations.

Ethnographic fieldwork revealed a prominent discourse within the humanitarian sector about differences in gendered social norms between Jordanians and Syrians, including those shaping reproduction. Syrian women were stereotypically described as marrying too early, having too many children, and being generally less "empowered" in comparison to Jordanian women who, conversely, were seen as more educated and whose lives were generally understood to be less defined by "customs and tradition." Although, statistically speaking, the particular population of Syrians residing in Jordan does have a higher average fertility rate and lower age at marriage, these differences fade or even disappear entirely when variations in class and residential (rural versus urban) background are taken into account. Nevertheless, nationality was overwhelmingly referred to as the source of differences in gender norms during interviews with expatriate and Jordanian humanitarian workers.

Syrian women's understandings of their own reproductive lives was often shaped by the ways in they positioned themselves in relation to this discourse. At one extreme--which, not coincidentally, appeared frequently during interviews with participants recruited via NGOs and sometimes conducted by NGO staff--women described a profound, positive transformation in gender roles triggered by their displacement to Jordan. According to these accounts, in Jordan they learned that they had rights and began to stand up for themselves or even, in the words of several participants, became more like Jordanian women. Other women observed that life in Jordan had led them to have fewer children but viewed this as a necessary rather than desirable adaptation to the economic hardship, material scarcity, and general precarity they faced as refugees. On the other end of the spectrum were women who fundamentally disagreed with the prominent claims made by humanitarian organizations that early marriage is harmful for adolescent girls. Some of these women saw early marriage as a means of protecting a girl from harassment, safeguarding her reputation, maximizing her prospects for marriage to a good man from a good family, or ensuring her access to resources and ultimately a better life that her natal family was unable to otherwise provide for her.

The nuanced, contextualized accounts of reproductive experience collected during this study counter prominent, often-essentializing representations of Syrian women's reproductive health challenges. Publications resulting from this study not only contribute to anthropological understandings of reproductive subjectivity but also provide novel, concrete recommendations for conducting research with displaced populations relevant to a wide variety of disciplines. The larger dissertation project considers why ethnography so often reveals crucial aspects of everyday life that are extremely relevant to understanding health yet rarely captured though more applied, action-oriented public health methodologies and reflects on how lessons learned through ethnographic research could inform--and even transform--the ways in which knowledge about the health of marginalized populations is produced far beyond the discipline of anthropology.
